Message.Title: FBI and SEC team up...
Message.Msg: Article on ZH. They should have an absolute field day here. I certainly have documented some highly suspicious/irregular activity for them... They are catching on to the float jam scam enabled by market structure and executed by the quants here... There is a reason the NY Fed works with HFT-giant Citadel: it is precisely to facilitate what HFT is "accused" of doing. But one can't go and expose all the manipulated secrets that have sent this fake market to even faker all time highs. Authorities are exploring potential holes in the system, including new algorithms referred to as “news aggregation” which search the internet, news sites and social media for selected keywords, and fire off orders in milliseconds. The trades are so quick, often before the information is widely disseminated, that authorities are debating whether they violate insider trading rules, the people familiar with the matter said. Authorities are also monitoring alpha capture systems, platforms where sell-side firms share information with buyside professionals, for potential front running or insider trading. Also on their radar is artificial intelligence trading, an algorithm that predicts market reactions based on history. One can see it already: "it was all Twitter's fault.""Nonetheless, there is at least a trace reason to be hopeful: One government official said market structure could be the next big area for cases, although it was not clear whether any of the strategies violated criminal laws. To prove a criminal case the FBI would need to show that the trader intended to manipulate the stock, which could prove more difficult for strategies that are triggered by computers.

Topic.Title: Amazon starts to lose momentum and they use AAPL as a source to prop it again...

Message.Msg: No Bruce. I see the fundamentals in the economy which are being managed as aggressively as they can be. US and Global GDP growth would be negative absent increases in gov't debt enabled my money printing that do not count against GDP. The increase in debt in the US was 3X the increase in GDP in 2012. Same thing is happening in Japan and Europe. There's much more to the story... Equity largely be wiped out moving forward increasing debt is required to sustain fake nominal growth. The US equity markets are a relative bubble to the rest of the world. But, discussing them in aggregate hides the extent of the bubble because companies like AAPL and INTC are trading at low EBITDA multiples. The bubble in Scamazon, LNKD and elsewhere, which exists purely to enable trading profits until they cannot anymore, are insane. Laugh now. This is going to be epically ugly because the option/algo scamming framework is overextending wide swaths of the market the way that NFLX, CMG and GMCR were overextended...

Message.Msg: Debt? What debt? All we have to do is print million dollar bills and send them to everyone holding our debt. EBITDA isn't important, free cash flow is. Amazon has been through it before, they've lost 80%, but they always come back. It's a no risk investment.

Topic.Title: Amazon starts to lose momentum and they use AAPL as a source to prop it again...

Message.Msg: Bruce, do you realize what EBITDA is? Amazon's true FCF is actually much worse because most of its CapEx needs relatively rapid replacements (a significant fraction of the fulfillment center buildout is off balance sheet...) -- like AWS/cloud infrastructure. Amazon certainly could lose 80% again. Its competitive set now is very different that the mom and pop retailers it took out in the last wave. Now, it has to knock out TGT, WMT, COST, EBAY and GOOG. The 3 former have already built out a wider distribution/retail network and do not require the ongoing investment to the same extent. The latter two have vastly superior margin and cash flow from which to strategically acquire the physical network as needed and at a discount, as opposed to Amazon's massive malinvestment approach. This time is different. Amazon is a $100B plus market cap company. It will not recover this time. And, it has material risk of insolvency given the right macro shock. Any institutional long not aggressively rebalancing toward AAPL at these levels is negligent IMHO...

Topic.Title: shorts are defeated : not posting today: techstrategy is fatigued and gutted by his AMZN losses

Message.Msg: Kenji: I'm serious when I say that this #$%$ has to be stopped. People have no idea the systemic fragility that is is causing. All the pundits talk about the market as monolithic. It is not. Real companies engaged in value creating, productive investment are systematically hurt by the algorithmic trading/option scalping scam. Float jam scam MOMO companies are lifted. The collateral damage is a strong disincentive for business models that depend upon productive investment that enhances productivity and creates value in favor of those that engage in value destroying revenue growth (for the MOMO play) or trading (which simply redistributes from one party to the next). When our capital is directed to that which destroys or redistributes, the LT impact on the domestic economy is clear... I have statistical analysis of multiple expansion/contraction as a function of earnings growth, revenue growth and institutional control of float that I am working on packaging. Control for sector level effects (with restaurant or retail for example) and use some event modeling (as in, when did these stocks get weekly options) and you see some rather interesting patterns. I may lose my tail on this, but I will not rest until some justice gets served (I get to use my econometric modeling skills). My posting will diminish. But, my commitment to exposing this scam for what it is grows by the day. And it seems there is now a forum for directly addressing the market structure float jam scam....

Message.Msg: If by condition you mean my determination to see justice done to those who have manipulated this stock (and AAPL's in the reverse direction to enable a massive dumping of shares of overvalued AMZN/MOMO #$%$ onto index tracking ETFs thereby screwing retail which increasingly relies upon them), then you are correct. The market manipulation that has led to this valuation is a scam that dwarfs Enron. The collateral damage from what is being done is orders of magnitude greater. As companies like INTC get HAMMERED for commitments to productive investment in cutting edge manufacturing capacity, companies like AMZN get rewarded for investing in redundant, value destroying distribution infrastructure (because we do not have enough...). It would not be happening but for the float jam manipulation scam that systematically suppresses the value of real investments and inflates bubblicious MOMO scams, all to extract scalping profits from those who realize the disconnect in valuations on each side... Keep talking smack Geeg. Once the AAPL/GLD knockout trade ceases, the Fed POMO will be inadequate to maintain this scam and AMZN will crater. The fundamentals I have commented on will play out and what I have said will become clear to all...

Message.Title: Tulips, Studabakers, and AMZN
Message.Msg: When the Lemmings finally realize others can raise tulips for less and Amazon will take the biggest hit as more sales taxes kick in, the fad that lasted so long will be history like bell bottom pants and the Studabaker automobile. Amazon just resells. They do not produce. That is not the way to make big bucks.

Topic.Title: FBI and SEC team up...

Message.Msg: Hi Tech: I am also interested in busting this manipulation by the big guys via their algos and quant funds which are only fronts for manipulating stock prices. I agree that savings and investments should be focused on economic activity that creates value and jobs - not these paper profits that don't do anybody any good in the long run including those that think they are getting rich (they should look at Zimbabwe). I could not find your mail id through your alias - can you please contact me at 510 326 5609 or at my email id chandru dot betonamerica dot org. Thanks.

Topic.Title: FBI and SEC team up...

Message.Msg: I like the URL. I am still a bull on this country, but only if we can end these BS trading scams that siphon capital away from productive investment. The INTC versus AMZN is a perfect case study on how the broken market is damaging my children's future. Altera moving to INTC as a foundry is only the beginning. Just wait. Anyone manufacturing sophisticated communications chips will be making that change in the coming year or two. It is TSMC that is in trouble... Meanwhile, Amazon has locked themselves into a cost structure and commitments to vendors and customers that could prove its downfall. But, it is rewarded with pumpgrades. WS needs to start generating value by directing resources to truly productive investments again, rather than running a glorified skimming operation...

Topic.Title: tceh how is lenin doing

Message.Msg: Cash: First, how 'bout the Hawks? Helluva start.... Second, I have no interest in selling my 3 flat. It generates cash flow in excess of its fixed interest service cost and is slowly building equity. Should we get hyperinflation, only my energy and taxes increase, while rents increase more. My 3 flat is actually a reasonable hedge as a physical asset against the central bank printing (which the Fed is using to buy all the mortgages to gain physical collateral to augment its real or imaginary gold holdings...). In contrast, Amazon's cash flow isn't 20% overvalued, it is more than 100% overvalued. Beyond that, it is NOT a good hyperinflation hedge. Its relative cost competitiveness declines in a world of "inflation" and its future cash flows become more challenged, not less. Furthermore, AAPL and GLD are being taken down deliberately in this scam market, where they will actually benefit and see increased relative value from the "inflationary" pressures (let's be honest and just call it money printing to try to sustain the nominal asset values of financial assets). In short, this isn't about a scam market of inflated values across the board. This is a predatory move driven by certain institutions using money printed out of thin air (and virtually unlimited leverage to which only they get access) to beat down and shake out those who were acting like real investors and positioned themselves rationally given the state of the economy. Note that short interest is decreasing in all MOMO scams (probably driven by big boys deciding not to loan shares short in MOMO scams) while growing in relatively undervalued large cap tech (reaching near all time highs in INTC, nearly double last year in AAPL). This country isn't remotely done. We just need to stop believing that "price is truth" and that the capital markets reflect real world value. We need to invest in the real rather than the financial economy as the latter is simply a tax...

Topic.Title: tceh how is lenin doing

Message.Msg: Who would you bet on? Japan (will likely be the match that lights the powder keg with its stupidity of shutting down all nuclear and ensuring that a weaker yen will not improve the weakening trade situation) and with ridiculous demographic crisis? Europe, which outside of Germany is hosed? China, which despite its industrial might still has to maintain stability with a population of 1.3B people who have increasing expectation for standard of living? Saudi Arabia or Middle East oil states that face a constant threat of terrorism? Russia, the paragon of honest business? Brazil, which has massive poverty and is rapidly consuming its natural resource base? Only Canada and Australia realistically can/will maintain a relatively similar (median) standard of living to us. Eventually, we'll become a little more strategic, building the Keystone for a strategic capacity buffer (via tar sands and Bakken oil to our refineries) to reduce Saudi/OPEC supply leverage and better control oil / gas prices. Further, if we were strategic and banned export of refined product (an idea which I am sure will engender angry response from laissez faire free traders here), global gasoline prices would likely spike while oil prices drop from end use demand destruction outside the US... Which would in turn put pressure on the OPEC cartel as more would cheat, further reducing oil prices. It's called competitive strategy. Others are doing it to us. We are getting played all the time... There's plenty we could do to right this ship. But, its going to require people pushing back against the status quo. The analysis I am pulling together is my little way of pushing back...
